DataElement.preferredName: MAML2 Gene Chromosomal Translocation Identification Type
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Text term that represents the specific exon identified with the MAML2 chromosomal translocation.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: This gene plays a role in transcriptional regulation and signal transduction.: This gene is involved in transcriptional regulation.: A hybrid gene created by joining portions of two different genes (to produce a new protein) or by joining a gene to a different promoter (to alter or regulate gene transcription). These can be created by chromosomal aberration or by laboratory methods.

Concepts.definition: This gene plays a role in transcriptional regulation and signal transduction.
This gene is involved in transcriptional regulation.

A hybrid gene created by joining portions of two different genes (to produce a new protein) or by joining a gene to a different promoter (to alter or regulate gene transcription). These can be created by chromosomal aberration or by laboratory methods.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A fusion gene (~3.8 kb) that results from a chromosomal translocation t(11;19)(q14-q21;p13-p12) which fuses exon 1 of the CRTC1 gene to exons 2-5 of the MAML2 gene. This rearrangement is associated with mucoepidermoid carcinoma, Warthin's tumor and clear cell hidradenoma.

Concepts.definition: A fusion gene (~3.8 kb) that results from a chromosomal translocation t(11;19)(q14-q21;p13-p12) which fuses exon 1 of the CRTC1 gene to exons 2-5 of the MAML2 gene. This rearrangement is associated with mucoepidermoid carcinoma, Warthin's tumor and clear cell hidradenoma.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.: Any type of genetic recombination involving exchange of DNA between non-homologous chromosomes, which often occurs as the result of non-homologous end-joining of broken DNA strands. Chromosomal translocation is involved in repairing broken DNA and in maintaining cell viability at the expense of long term genomic stability. This process is is associated with particular types of leukemia, infertility and Down Syndrome.

Concepts.definition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

Any type of genetic recombination involving exchange of DNA between non-homologous chromosomes, which often occurs as the result of non-homologous end-joining of broken DNA strands. Chromosomal translocation is involved in repairing broken DNA and in maintaining cell viability at the expense of long term genomic stability. This process is is associated with particular types of leukemia, infertility and Down Syndrome.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Specification of human conditions relevant to cancer. This includes observations, test results, history, and other concepts relevant to characterization of human cancer-related conditions. Non-neoplastic conditions of interest are also included.
